Rand Paul promotes criminal-justice reforms Associated Press 10:33 a.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Rand Paul talks to WHAS11 political editor Joe Arnold on June 1, 2015 (Photo: WHAS) CONNECT TWEET   
LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Republican presidential candidate Rand Paul visited a mostly minority section of Louisville to promote criminal-justice reforms and tax breaks to stimulate job growth in struggling neighborhoods. On Friday, the Kentucky senator toured America's Finest Filters, a business in western Louisville. The company's president and CEO, Michael White, said nearly half of his 19 employees were previously convicted of felonies. White says he believes in giving people a second chance. Paul pitched his efforts to revamp the nation's drug and sentencing laws. It's part of his campaign to lure more minority voters to the GOP. Paul criticized disparities resulting in higher percentages of blacks going to prison for drug offenses.
